comments.author: NotFlameRetardant

What do you mean by this? Posts are sorted by "hot" (determined by reddit's algorithm) by default, unless you personally switch how your feed is sorted. As far as comment threads go, there isn't a default for this subreddit specifically, which falls back to "best" (also determined by reddit's algorithm).

If you want to change the sort order to chronological for posts & comments in specific subreddits, you have to change your personal settings under Profile -> Feed Settings -> Community Content Sort (check "new" if you want that behavior to affect all subreddits, otherwise go to the next step) -> Check "Remember per community", which means it'll remain globally the same except for specific subreddit overrides, where it'll retain your setting as "new" for those specific subreddits once you change one comment thread to that setting.

comments.author: NotFlameRetardant
comments.body:
Hard agree on all of that. Also, coal isn't just polluting in a typical emissions sense - it's also the worst energy source from a radiation perspective, The byproducts released from coal burning plants accounts for more environmental radiation than all nuclear disasters combined given coal is naturally radioactive.

Fukushima was less than 15 years ago so the long-long term cancer rate data is still yet TBD, but for deaths in that timeframe - 1 person died from cancer 4 years later (51 deaths occurred as a result of the evacuation of 164,000 surrounding the plant), and 6 were suspected to have gotten cancer/leukemia as a result of their exposure. The WHO found In 2013, that "residents of the area who were evacuated were exposed to so little radiation that radiation induced health impacts are likely to be below detectable levels".

Compare that to rural Kentucky, where residents who are close to coal mines or plants having cancer rates about 50% higher than rural Kentucky residents who are not near coal mines/plants.

Coal production is extremely fucking dirty.
